p.s: The sonnet Sonnet 116 by William Shakespeare is about the idea of love.
First the speaker describes what love is, by describing what love isn't (cf. l. 3f.).
In this first quatrain Love is described as something which doesn't change.
After that, in the second quatrain in the speaker compares love to a ever-fixed mark (cf. l. 5).
It seems far away (cf. l. 8), but the love is always there (cf. l. 5-7).
The third quatrain is about the immortality of love and that love doesn't change with the time (cf. l. 9-12).
In the last couplet the speaker underlines his idea of love, by saying that he never write and no man has ever loven, if he is wrong (cf. l. 13f).
All in all the idea of love from the the speaker gets clear, by first describing and then comparin it.
